subject: Entrepreneurship
subcategory: Business Models That Changed the World
title: When the Razor-Blade Model Backfires
description: A micro-lesson that makes When the Razor-Blade Model Backfires usable.

hook.text: Dollar Shave Club proved that razor blades don't need to be expensive. Gillette's lock-in shattered.

buildup.text: The razor-blade model works only when customers can't easily find alternatives.

discovery.text: Three forces break the model: third-party alternatives, customer backlash, and regulatory pressure.

twist.text: Keurig, HP, and Gillette all faced revolts. Customers found generic pods, refilled ink, and switched brands.

climax.text: The internet made it easy to find cheaper alternatives, weakening lock-in strategies everywhere.

punchline.text: Lock-in worksâ€”until customers find the exit.

quiz.question: What is the biggest threat to the razor-blade business model?
options: Rising manufacturing costs for the base product
Easy access to third-party alternatives and informed consumers
